text.headline: Hirahara Photographs Timeline
text.text: CollectionBuilder-CONTENTdm is a template for creating digital collection exhibits on top of existing CONTENTdm repositories. This demo features materials from the George and Frank C. Hirahara Photograph Collection, 1943-1945 from Washington State University.

media.caption: Five students dressed in caps and gowns in front of banners and plants, 1944.

text.headline: Five students dressed in caps and gowns in front of banners and plants, 1944.
text.text: Photograph of Kazuo Hashitsume, Hiroshi Komatsu, Masaru Kuraoka, Shigeru Matsumura, and Tomio Yamawaki dressed in caps and gowns posing inside of a building  for a graduation picture, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.  Decorative plants have been placed behind and next to the students.  There are also two banners, a Japanese style landscape, and a wind sock in the shape of a fish behind the students.  This photograph is similar to another photograph in the collection (sc14b01f0168n01).

media.caption: Boy Scout leaders and Boy Scouts holding their district flag, 1944.

text.headline: Boy Scout leaders and Boy Scouts holding their district flag, 1944.
text.text: Photograph of Boy Scout leaders from Troop 333, including Stanley Yoshida,  Kenneth Shibata,  Sutter Kajita, and Ernest Kajita with Scoutmaster Saburo Fujise. In 1944, Troop 333 was declared winner of their District Flag. This photograph shows Scoutmaster Saburo Fujise kneeling beneath the flag held by the Scout leaders and two members of the Troop  outside at Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.

media.caption: Boy Scouts Troop 333 gathered outside for a portrait, 1944.

text.headline: Boy Scouts Troop 333 gathered outside for a portrait, 1944.
text.text: Members of Boy Scout Troop 333 gathered outside for a portrait, May 31, 1944.  Kneeling in the front row are (L-R) George Fujikawa, Donald Yamamoto, Kaz Shiroyama, George Iwasa, Kenny Yoshikura, Charles Uyeda, Joe Ogata, Hiroshi Bill Shishima, Yuji Gabby Hirata, and Tadao Ito.  Standing in the back row are (L-R) Toru Shibata, William Yamamoto, Stanley Yoshida, Scoutmaster Saburo Fujise, Nob Shimokochi, Mikio Ito, Ernie Kajita, Kenny Shibata, Sutter Kajita, Kenji Hamanaka, and Yoshimi Watanabe. Boy Scout Troop 333 won their district flag in May 1944.

media.caption: Arts and crafts fair inside of a recreation hall.

text.headline: Arts and crafts fair inside of a recreation hall.
text.text: Photograph of arts and crafts displayed at the Craft Fair inside of a Recreation Hall, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming. Representative works from the crochet, embroidery, fine arts, and floral arrangement classes were shown in the first combined handicraft exhibit on February 12 and 14, 1944 in the Heart Mountain 21-25 Mess Hall under the sponsorship of the Adult Education department. Some of the crafts are Japanese in inspiration, such as a bonzai tree, a noh mask, and a relief of an Asian deity. Instructors of the various classes were Mrs. Kimi Ito, crochet; Isaburo Nagahama and Mrs. H. Iwahashi, embroidery; Benji Okubo, fine arts; and Mrs. Shigee Homma, floral arrangement.

media.caption: Mike Hide and Etsuo Hiraishi making mochitsuki inside of a mess hall 15-30, February 4, 1945.

The men are swinging wooden mallets used to pound the mochi.  Mochitsuki is a traditional food for New Years.  In 1945, the lunar new year (Chinese New Year) fell on February 13.

Masuda was a former resident of Auburn, Washington and Okada a resident of Tacoma who was visiting Heart Mountain from Ogden, Utah, where he had been on seasonal leave.

text.headline: Five students dressed in caps and gowns in front of banners and plants, 1944.
text.text: Photograph of Kazuo Hashitsume, Hiroshi Komatsu, Masaru Kuraoka, Shigeru Matsumura, and Tomio Yamawaki dressed in caps and gowns posing inside of a building  for a graduation picture, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.  Decorative plants have been placed behind and next to the students.  There are also two banners, a Japanese style landscape, and a wind sock in the shape of a fish behind the students.  This photograph is similar to another photograph in the collection (sc14b01f0367n01).

media.caption: Mrs. Tanaka and her students standing together outside of the Heart Mountain School.

media.caption: Group of school administrators standing on stage for the Heart Mountain High School graduation ceremony, May 24, 1945.

text.headline: Group of school administrators standing on stage for the Heart Mountain High School graduation ceremony, May 24, 1945.
text.text: Photograph of Heart Mountain High School Principal John K. Corbett, Reverend J. Clyde Keegan of the Cody Methodist Church, Project Director Guy Robertson, Commencement speaker Dr. L. R. Kilzer, Director of Education at the University of Wyoming Keen Yanagi, and Vice Principal Ralph A. Forsythe standing on the school stage with the school band playing below for the Heart Mountain  High School graduation commencement, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.  The ceremony was held in the gymnasium.

media.caption: Crowd at the Heart Mountain High School graduation, May 24, 1945.

text.headline: Crowd at the Heart Mountain High School graduation, May 24, 1945.
text.text: Photograph of the crowd at the Heart Mountain High School graduation commencement, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.  The audience is standing in the bleachers.  The ceremony was held in the gymnasium.

media.caption: Crowd at the Heart Mountain High School graduation, May 24, 1945.

text.headline: Crowd at the Heart Mountain High School graduation, May 24, 1945.
text.text: Photograph of the crowd at the Heart Mountain High School graduation commencement, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.  The audience is standing in the bleachers.  A few men in military uniforms stand in the last rows of bleachers.  The ceremony was held in the gymnasium.

media.caption: Procession of students through the gymnasium for the Heart Mountain High School graduation, May 24, 1945.

text.headline: Procession of students through the gymnasium for the Heart Mountain High School graduation, May 24, 1945.
text.text: Photograph of the precession of 250 high school students through the gymnasium for the Heart Mountain High School graduation commencement, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.  The students are wearing caps and gowns.  The ceremony was held in the gymnasium.

text.text: Photograph of Ms. Clarissa Corbett watching two students cooking in a home economic class at Heart Mountain  School, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.  One student is stirring a pot on a stove.  The other student is mixing ingredients with an egg beater.

One student holds a ball in his right hand.  The other student is ducking his head as if to avoid a tag.  A third student with a glove and cap approaches from the right.

media.caption: Uyehara family outside of their family barrack.

text.headline: Uyehara family outside of their family barrack.
text.text: Photograph of the Uyehara family. The Koyamas are on the left of the photo. They include Tazu, Jack, who is squatting, and their child Jackie. Kenji (Ray) Uyehara holds his daughter Marlene and stands next to Tazu. Toshiye (Mary or Tootsie) Uyehara stands on the right side of the photo holding her son David. Shigeno Yamamoto stands behind her grandchildren, Raymond, Jr., and Robert Uyehara. Tazu and Jack Koyama are the Uyehara children's aunt and uncle. The photograph was taken outside of the Uyehara family barrack 15-10-C, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.

media.caption: Koto Hirahara and Private First Class Sumiji Tamaki standing outside, June 11, 1944.

text.headline: Koto Hirahara and Private First Class Sumiji Tamaki standing outside, June 11, 1944.

This was the second visit for Sumiji Tamaki to Heart Mountain. This time on furlough from Camp Shelby to visit the Hirahara Family.

media.caption: Portrait of the Nakatsuka family with photograph of son-in-law Keiji, January 12, 1945.

The photograph on the table is Itsui Nakatsu's husband Keiji, who was serving in the United States military when this photograph was taken. This a family portrait was a tribute to Yoshimichi, the son of Atsumu Nakatsuka, who died at Heart Mountain in 1942, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.

media.caption: Woman looking out the window of a departing train, June 18, 1945.

text.headline: Woman looking out the window of a departing train, June 18, 1945.
text.text: Photograph of people talking to people boarded on a departing train, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.  The passengers on the train are leaving Heart Mountain to resettle elsewhere.  A woman looking the window of the train appears to be smiling.  She also appears in a group photo taken on the same day that included members of the Nomura family (sc14b01f224n02).  The passengers on the train are leaving Heart Mountain to resettle elsewhere.

The passengers on the train are leaving Heart Mountain to resettle elsewhere.  The photograph is taken from an elevated position behind the crowd.  A sign on the train lists a number of destinations in California.

media.caption: Kunio Yamamoto facing Heart Mountain, 1944.

text.text: Photograph of Kunio Yamamoto standing outside of the barracks and facing Heart Mountain, Heart Mountain Relocation Center, Wyoming.  Yamamoto looks past a row of barracks toward Heart Mountain, as he casts a shadow toward the camera.  Yamamoto's back is to the photographer.  This photograph is a closer view of another image in the collection (sc14b01b083n04).

Bouquets of flowers stand next to the casket.  Buddhist reverends stand on both sides of the casket.  Flowers stand along side and atop the casket.
